choices.text: NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased.
Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle.
Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased.
The major fuel used by the brain is glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately reflects a metabolic characteristic of the well-fed state
questions.solution:
Ans. D)   The major fuel used by the brain is glucose.

 

Option D:

 

  • Glucose is the major fuel for the brain in the well-fed state and requires a continuous supply of it.
  • During starvation or fasting, the brain obtains approximately 75% of its energy from circulating ketone bodies.              

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased: Liver production of NADPH is at a high level because it is needed for fatty acid synthesis.

 

Option B.  Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle: During the absorptive phase, ketone bodies such as acetoacetate and 3-hydroxybutyrate are low  with glucose rather than these ketones used by muscle.

 

Option C.  Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased: Glucose is actively transported into all cells, including adipocytes, which require it to form glycerol-3-phosphate for esterification of fatty acids into triacylglycerides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a well-fed state, the brain continues to use glucose as its primary energy source. The blood glucose levels are sufficient, and insulin facilitates glucose uptake into the brain cells.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 101.

choices.text: Heat stable, dialyzable, non protein organic molecules

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a diagnosis of beriberi is found to have a deficiency in thiamine, a vital nutrient in her diet. Her physician explains the significance of thiamine as it relates to her condition and its role in enzymatic processes within the body. Based on this, which of the following best characterizes coenzymes like thiamine in their role in enzymatic reactions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heat stable, dialyzable, non protein organic molecules

 

Option A.

 

  1. The coenzyme is a non-protein part of the enzyme,
  2. The coenzyme is needed for the biological activity of the enzyme.
  3. They are generally low molecular weight organic substances.
  4. They are mostly heat stable.
  5. The coenzymes combine loosely with the enzyme molecules and both can be separated easily by dialysis.
  6. Once the reaction is completed, the coenzyme is released from the apoenzyme and can bind to another enzyme molecule.
  7. One molecule of the coenzyme is able to convert a large number of substrate molecules with the help of enzyme.
  8. Most of the coenzymes are derivatives of vitamin B-complex group of substances.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Soluble, colloidal, protein molecules: This description more accurately pertains to enzymes themselves, which are proteinaceous in nature, rather than coenzymes. Coenzymes are not proteins but work alongside enzymes.

 

Option C. Structural analog of enzymes: Coenzymes are not structural analogs of enzymes. Instead, they are distinct molecules that assist the catalytic activity of enzymes.

 

Option D. Different forms of enzymes: Coenzymes are not alternative forms of enzymes. They are separate, non-protein entities that bind to enzymes and participate in the catalytic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coenzymes are typically small, heat-stable, non-protein organic molecules that assist enzymes in catalyzing reactions. They often function as carriers of electrons, atoms, or functional groups. Being dialyzable, they can pass through semi-permeable membranes, which is not characteristic of larger protein molecules.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 49, 50.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a known history of coronary artery disease (CAD) undergoes his annual health check-up. Laboratory investigations indicate elevated levels of LDH-5. The consulting cardiologist reviews these results to determine the potential source of cell injury. LDH, or lactate dehydrogenase, has several isoenzymes with different tissue distributions. Based on the elevation of LDH-5, which tissue is most likely experiencing injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Liver

 

Option B.

 

  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) is a tetrameric enzyme consisting of two monomer types: H (for heart) and M (for muscle) that combine to give five LDH isozymes.
  • HHHH (I1), HHHM (I2), HHMM (I3), HMMM (I4), and MMMM (I5).
  • Tissue-specific expression of the H and M genes determines the proportions of each subunit in different tissues.
  • Isozyme LDH-I is seen in heart tissue, and isozyme LDH-5 is in the liver.
  • Thus, any tissue injury causes releases of characteristic pattern of LDH isozymes.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Heart: Isozyme LDH 1 is seen in Heart.

 

Option C. Brain: Isozyme LDH 3 is seen in Brain.

 

Option D. RBC: Isozyme LDH 2 is seen in RBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDH-5 is an isoenzyme of lactate dehydrogenase that is most abundant in the liver and skeletal muscle. Elevated levels of LDH-5 are often associated with liver damage or disease, reflecting hepatocellular injury. While LDH is a fairly non-specific marker and can be elevated in various conditions, the specific elevation of LDH-5 is more suggestive of liver involvement rather than heart, brain, or red blood cells.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 66.

questions.text: MATCH THE FOLLOWING:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  • Statins inhibit HMG CoA Reductase (d), a key enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis.
  • Dicoumarol inhibits Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (c), affecting the clotting cascade.
  • Methotrexate inhibits Dihydrofolate Reductase (b), used in cancer therapy and autoimmune diseases.
  • Succinyl Choline is not an enzyme inhibitor but a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonist used as a neuromuscular blocker; however, in the context of this question, it's matched with Acetylcholinesterase (a) by process of elimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibitors of enzymes are mostly drugs

 

 

Some competitive inhibitors which are not drugs are

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 81-84.

questions.text: A teenager is brought to the ER with symptoms of increased confusion and lethargy. Lab tests reveal abnormal liver function and significantly elevated serum ammonia levels. His parents note his recent high protein intake, attributed to his athletic activities. Hyperammonemia can disrupt the TCA cycle by depleting a specific intermediate, leading to impaired energy metabolism. Which TCA cycle intermediate is most likely depleted in this scenario, contributing to the cycle's inhibition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) α-ketoglutarate  

 

Option C:

 

 

  • Since ammonia is toxic to CNS, it is important to maintain only traces (10-20 μg/dL) in peripheral blood and it should be effectively detoxified and eliminated from the body.
  • In severely impaired hepatic function or the development of collateral links between the portal and systemic veins in cirrhosis, portal blood bypasses the liver, systemic blood ammonia may attain toxic levels.
  • Symptoms of ammonia intoxication include tremor, slurred speech, blurred vision, coma, and ultimately death.
  • Ammonia may be toxic to the brain in part because it reacts with α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate.
  • The resulting depletion of levels of α-ketoglutarate then impairs function of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle in neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

Option A. Aspartate:  Although aspartate is involved in the urea cycle, its depletion does not directly inhibit the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Malate:  Malate is a TCA cycle intermediate, but it is not directly depleted by hyperammonemia.

 

Option D. Fumarate:  Fumarate is also part of the TCA cycle but is not the intermediate depleted by hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperammonemia can inhibit the TCA cycle by depleting α-ketoglutarate. Ammonia is detoxified in the liver by the urea cycle, which consumes α-ketoglutarate as it combines with ammonia to form glutamate. This process depletes α-ketoglutarate, a critical intermediate in the TCA cycle, leading to impaired energy metabolism and contributing to the symptoms observed.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 291, 292, Lippincott: P 253.

questions.text: During a pediatric rotation, a medical student observes the management of a child presenting with acute gastroenteritis and signs of dehydration. The attending physician prescribes oral rehydration solution (ORS). The student learns that the efficacy of ORS is partly due to its facilitation of glucose absorption, which in turn enhances electrolyte and water uptake in the intestines. Which glucose transporter is primarily responsible for the glucose absorption facilitated by ORS in the intestinal mucosa?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

 

Option A:

 

  • Absorption from intestinal lumen into intestinal cell is by Sodium Dependent Glucose

 

 

  • Transporter-1 (SGLT-1), cotransport mechanism (secondary active transport)
  • A membrane bound carrier protein is involved, which carries glucose, along with sodium → sodium is later expelled by the sodium pump with utilization of energy.
  • The transporter in the intestine is SGLT-1 involved in glucose-galactose malabsorption and in the kidney is SGLT-2 which is defective in congenital renal glycosuria.
  • Clinical application: Common treatment for diarrhoea is oral rehydration fluid, which contains both glucose and sodium → allows absorption of sodium to replenish body sodium chloride levels and glucose to provide energy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.  SGLT-2: SGLT-2 is defective in congenital renal glycosuria

 

Option C. GLUT 4:  Insulin-mediated glucose uptake. Involved in Type 2 diabetes mellitus

 

Option D.  GLUT 2: Enables the pancreas to monitor the glucose level, thereby adjusts the rate of insulin secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT 1 (sodium-glucose cotransporter 1) is responsible for the absorption of glucose in the small intestine. It cotransports sodium and glucose from the intestinal lumen into enterocytes, thereby facilitating the absorption of water and electrolytes, which is the principle behind the effectiveness of ORS.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 106.

questions.text: Match the clinically useful competitive inhibitors with the drug:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

Explanation:

A. Allopurinol is a competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, an enzyme involved in the pathway that leads to uric acid production. Therefore, it is used in the treatment of gout.

B. Sulfonamide is a competitive inhibitor of pteroid synthetase (also known as dihydropteroate synthase), an enzyme involved in folate synthesis in bacteria.

C. 5-fluorouracil is a competitive inhibitor of thymidylate synthase, an enzyme involved in the synthesis of the nucleotide thymidine, which is required for DNA replication.

D. Trimethoprim is a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme involved in the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for the production of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 61

choices.text: Oxidation step between cytochrome and coenzyme Q and distal cytochromes
Oxidation step involving direct reduction of oxygen
Oxidation step between cytochromes c and b

questions.text: Many compounds poison the respiratory chain by inhibiting various steps of oxidation or phosphorylation. Which of the following steps is inhibited by carbon monoxide and cyanide?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oxidation step involving direct reduction of oxygen)

 

Option B:

 

Carbon monoxide (CO) and cyanide (CN-) inhibit the respiratory chain by binding to cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV), which is responsible for the direct reduction of oxygen to water in the final step of the electron transport chain. This binding prevents oxygen from being reduced, effectively halting the electron transport chain and disrupting ATP production, leading to cellular energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The step involving coenzyme Q and distal cytochromes is not the specific target of CO and CN-; these compounds specifically inhibit Complex IV.

 

Option C: CO and CN- do not uncouple oxidation from phosphorylation; they directly inhibit electron transfer to oxygen.

 

Option D: The step between cytochromes c and b is not directly inhibited by these compounds; their inhibitory effect is on the terminal step involving oxygen reduction by cytochrome c oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carbon monoxide and cyanide inhibit cytochrome oxidase, the terminal step of the respiratory chain that is driven by oxygen reduction to water
  • Barbiturates block transfer from cytochrome to coenzyme Q, antimycin A, and dimercaprol, the step between cytochromes c and b, and dinitrophenol is an uncoupler that releases the respiratory chain from regulation by energy (phosphorylation) needs. Oligomycin blocks phosphorylation by inhibiting ATP synthase, thus shutting down its coupled oxidation.

 

Ref: Harper Illustrated Biochemistry 31/e p 321-22.

questions.text: Cytochrome c, typically associated with the electron transport chain, also plays a role in mediating apoptosis. Is this statement true or false?.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

Cytochrome c indeed mediates apoptosis. Upon release from the mitochondria into the cytosol in response to apoptotic stimuli, cytochrome c interacts with Apaf-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor-1) and procaspase-9 to form the apoptosome. This complex initiates the caspase cascade, leading to the execution phase of apoptosis, characterized by cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and DNA fragmentation.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Cytochrome C is a mobile electron carrier between Complex III and Complex IV.
  • It plays an important role in programmed cell death.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p127-130.

questions.text: A 19-year-old African female presents with chronic, mild symptoms of sleeping sickness, persisting over two years. She is treated with difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO), known for its efficacy against trypanosomiasis. DFMO inhibits the enzyme involved in polyamine synthesis, crucial for the parasite's proliferation. Based on DFMO's mechanism, what type of enzyme inhibition does it exemplify?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Suicidal Inhibition

 

Option A.

 

  • It is also known as mechanism-based inactivation. 
  • Here the inhibitor makes use of the enzyme’s own reaction mechanism to inactivate it.
  • In suicide inhibition, the structural analog is converted to a more effective inhibitor with the help of the enzyme to be inhibited.
  • For example, ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) catalyzes the conversion of ornithine to putrescine which is important for polyamine synthesis. Thus, when the ODC in trypanosoma is inhibited → multiplication of the parasite is arrested. Therefore, inhibitors of ODC enzyme such as difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO) are found to be effective against trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).
  • A similar mechanism is noted in the case of Allopurinol which is oxidized by xanthine oxidase to alloxanthine which is a strong inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.
  • The anti-inflammatory action of Aspirin is based on the suicide inhibition. Arachidonic acid is converted to prostaglandin by the enzyme Cyclo-oxygenase.  Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in the active centre of cyclo-oxygenase, thus prostaglandin synthesis is inhibited and so inflammation subsides.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase, Fluoride inhibit enolase thereby consequently the glycolysis, Iodoacetate inhibit enzymes having –SH group in their active centers, BAL (dimercaprol) as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning etc.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive: Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan iso-enzyme) by phenylalanine.

 

Option D. Allosteric: ALA Synthase catalyse the first step in heme biosynthesis and the end product, heme will allosterically inhibit the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DFMO acts as a suicidal (or suicide) inhibitor by irreversibly binding to and inactivating ornithine decarboxylase, the enzyme responsible for polyamine synthesis essential for the growth and reproduction of Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite causing sleeping sickness. Suicidal inhibitors form a covalent bond with the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p78.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child, while playing, accidentally ingests a small amount of rat poison containing fluoroacetate, found in the cupboard. This substance reacts with oxaloacetate to produce fluorocitrate. Which major metabolic pathway is most likely to be inhibited by this poison?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TCA Cycle

 

Option D:

 

  • TCA Cycle is inhibited by Fluoroacetate, is an e.g., of suicidal inhibition.
  • Fluoroacetate first gets converted to Fluoroacetyl coA → condenses with Oxaloacetate → converted to Fluoro citrate → inhibit Aconitase enzyme of TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETC: Inhibitors includes Alkylguanides, hypotensive drug, Rotenone, insecticide and fish poison, Barbiturates, Carboxin, BAL, Naphthoquinone etc.

 

Option B. Glycolysis: Key enzymes such as HK, GK, PFK are inhibited by G-6-P, Glucagon, ATP, cyclic AMP, citrate, low pH, cAMP.

 

Option C. HMP shunt: G6PD is the rate-limiting step, inhibited by NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorocitrate, formed from the reaction of fluoroacetate with oxaloacetate, is a potent inhibitor of the TCA cycle. It specifically inhibits aconitase, an enzyme in the TCA cycle, thereby blocking the conversion of citrate to isocitrate and disrupting cellular energy production.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 161-163.

choices.text: 2,4-dinitrophenol is an allosteric activator of ATP synthase and thus increases the rate of H+ translocation and oxidation of fats and other fuels.
2,4-dinitrophenol inhibits transport of pyruvate into the mitochondria. Fats are therefore metabolized to glycerol and subsequently to pyruvate, depleting fat stores.
2,4-dinitrophenol allows oxidation of fats in adipose tissue without production of ATP. Fat oxidation can thus proceed continuously and fat stores will be used up.
2,4-dinitrophenol causes ATP to be produced at a higher rate than normal, thus causing weight loss.

questions.text: In the past, the uncoupler 2,4-dinitrophenol was used as a weight- reducing drug until side effects such as fatigue and breathlessness precluded its use. How could the use of this drug result in weight loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2,4 dinitrophenol allows oxidation of fats in adipose tissue without production of ATP. Fat oxidation can thus proceed continuously and fat stores will be used up.

 

Option C:

 

2,4-Dinitrophenol functions as an uncoupling agent in the mitochondrial electron transport chain. By disrupting the proton gradient across the mitochondrial inner membrane, it separates the processes of substrate oxidation from ATP synthesis. This decoupling leads to increased metabolic rate as energy from fat oxidation is released as heat instead of being used for ATP production. Consequently, fat stores are consumed at a higher rate to meet energy demands, leading to weight loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: 2,4-Dinitrophenol does not activate ATP synthase; it disrupts its function by preventing the establishment of a proton gradient necessary for ATP synthesis.

 

Option B: The compound does not specifically inhibit pyruvate transport into mitochondria; its primary action is on the proton gradient used in oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option D: 2,4-Dinitrophenol actually reduces the efficiency of ATP production by uncoupling oxidation from phosphorylation, leading to increased energy expenditure as heat rather than increased ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uncouplers such as 2,4-dinitrophenol dissociate oxidation from phosphorylation → ADP is not phosphorylated to produce ATP and respiration becomes uncontrolled as it tries to replenish ATP supplies → leads to increased metabolic turnover in the attempt to generate ATP. (Incorrect option A , B, D).
  • Less ADP will be converted to ATP → increased ADP and decreased rates of oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Prolonged energy deficits will lead to fatigue in energy-dependent tissues such as muscle or heart (cardiomyopathy), which is potentially lethal.

 

Ref: Harper Illustrated Biochemistry 31/e p 323-24.

questions.text: In a biochemistry class focused on enzyme inhibitors, the professor introduces the concept of "suicidal enzymes," which essentially undergo self-deactivation during the catalysis of their reactions. She then presents a list of enzymes and asks the students to identify which enzyme fits the description of a "suicidal enzyme." Which of the following enzymes is known to be a "suicidal enzyme"?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cyclooxygenase

 

Option B.

 

  1. Cyclooxygenase is a ‘Suicide Enzyme’ because ‘Switching off’ of prostaglandin activity is achieved by the self-catalyzed destruction property.
  2. Cyclooxygenase (COX) / Prostaglandin H synthase:
  • Involved in prostanoid (prostaglandin. Thromboxane and Prostacyclin) synthesis
  • This enzyme has two activities, a cyclooxygenase and peroxidase
  • COX is present as two isoenzymes, COX-1 and COX-2.
  1. Drugs acting as inhibitors of COX:

NSAID such as

  • Aspirin (Inhibits COX-1 and COX-2)
  • Indomethacin and ibuprofen (inhibit cyclooxygenases by competing with arachidonate)
  • Coxibs (Selectively inhibit COX-2)

Anti-inflammatory Corticosteroids

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lipoxygenase: This enzyme catalyzes the dioxygenation of polyunsaturated fatty acids in lipids. Although it participates in a reaction similar to that of COX, it is not commonly referred to as a suicidal enzyme.

 

Option C. Thromboxane Synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the formation of thromboxane from prostaglandin H2, but it is not classified as a suicidal enzyme.

 

Option D. 5’ Nucleotidase: This enzyme hydrolyzes phosphate groups from nucleotides and is not classified as a suicidal enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclooxygenase (COX) is often referred to as a "suicidal enzyme" because it permanently alters its active site during the process of converting arachidonic acid to prostaglandin H2, which eventually leads to the production of prostaglandins. The term "suicidal enzyme" is attributed to the fact that these enzymes undergo a one-time, self-destructive catalytic cycle after which they are no longer functional.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p241.

questions.text: What is the net change in the number of protons across the mitochondrial membrane for each set of two electrons transferred through Complexes I, III, and IV, respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4; 4; 2

 

Option B:

 

 

 

Complex I, also known as NADH: ubiquinone oxidoreductase, transfers two electrons from NADH to ubiquinone and pumps four protons across the mitochondrial membrane, resulting in a net change of 4 protons. Complex III, or cytochrome bc1 complex, transfers electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, moving four protons across the membrane for each set of two electrons, totaling a net change of 4 protons. Complex IV, known as cytochrome c oxidase, transfers electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, pumping only two protons across the membrane for each set of two electrons, leading to a net change of 2 protons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ETC: Complex-I /NADH-CoQ reductase or NADH dehydrogenase complex- It is tightly bound to the inner membrane of mitochondria → large negative free energy change occurs which is utilized to drive 4 protons out of the mitochondrial matrix into intermembrane space.
  • Complex III or Cytochrome Reductase -the free energy change through this complex due to electron transfer causes 4 protons to be pumped out.
  • Complex IV or Cytochrome Oxidase – It is tightly bound to the mitochondrial membrane, and pumps out 2 protons to the intermembrane space.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 131.
