choices.text: PDH complex is analogous to α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Fat can be converted to glucose, because PDH cycle is reversible
TPP, lipoic acid, coenzyme A, FAD, NAD are the coenzymes involved
PDH defect leads to lactic acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl CoA is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fat can be converted to glucose, because PDH cycle is reversible

 

Option B:

 

  1. PDH COMPLEX:
  • Pyruvate is oxidatively decarboxylated to Acetyl CoA
  • The oxidation of Pyruvate to Acetyl-CoA is the irreversible route from glycolysis to the citric Acid Cycle. No alternate pathway to circumvent this step
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (option A)
  • Multienzyme complex associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane
  1. PDH complex consists of 3 Enzymes: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase, Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase and Dihydrolipoyl Dehydrogenase.
  2. 5 Coenzymes (option C): Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), Lipoamide, Coenzyme A, FAD and NAD+
  3. PDH defect leads to lactic acidosis (option D)
  4. Completely irreversible process: (option B)

 

There is no pathway available in the body to circumvent this step and glucose through this step is converted to acetyl CoA from which fatty acids can be synthesized. But the backward reaction is not possible, and there is no net synthesis of glucose from fat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: True, the PDH complex is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex in terms of function and coenzyme requirements.

 

Option C: True, these coenzymes are all involved in the function of the PDH complex.

 

Option D: True, a defect in the PDH complex can lead to lactic acidosis because pyruvate is then preferentially converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA via the PDH complex is an irreversible step in metabolism. This means that fat, which is broken down into acetyl CoA, cannot be converted back to glucose through this pathway. This is a fundamental concept in metabolism, as it explains why fatty acids cannot undergo gluconeogenesis to form glucose.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 173, Vasudevan 9/ ed: p 115

choices.text: Trypsin is activated by the removal of a hexapeptide from C-terminal end
α 2-Macroglobulin is the major serine protease inhibitor of plasma
Chymotrypsin acts on peptide bonds in which the amino acid C-terminal to the bond is a tryptophan, tyrosine, phenylalanine.
Presence of Ser-His-Asp catalytic triad at the active site

questions.text: In a discussion on the biochemical properties of serine proteases, a molecular biologist outlines several characteristics common to this class of enzymes. Serine proteases play critical roles in various physiological processes, including digestion and coagulation. Which of the following features is universally found in all serine proteases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Presence of Ser-His-Asp catalytic triad at the active site. 

 

Option D.

 

  • Serine Proteases are proteolytic enzymes with Serine at their active Site
  • Amino acid triad in the active site of Serine Proteases: Ser, His, Asp.
  • Eg: Chymotrypsin, Trypsin, Elastase, Thrombin, Plasmin, Complements and Factor X and XI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trypsin is activated by the removal of a hexapeptide from N-terminal end.

 

Option B.α 1-Antitrypsin is the major serine protease inhibitor of plasma. Genetic deficiency of this protein results in emphysema and liver disease.

 

Option C. Chymotrypsin acts on peptide bonds formed in which the amino acid N-terminal to the bond is a tryptophan, tyrosine, phenylalanine

 

Educational Objective:

 

All serine proteases share a common catalytic mechanism that involves a conserved Ser-His-Asp triad at their active sites. This triad plays a crucial role in the catalytic activity of these enzymes, with the serine residue acting as a nucleophile in the cleavage of peptide bonds.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 62, 63.

choices.text: A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
A is right but R is a wrong statement
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion (A): After overnight fasting, levels of glucose transporters are reduced in adipocytes.

Reasoning (R): Adipocytes are insulin-sensitive tissues and as an early response to the hormone, the glucose transporters are externalized.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Option A:

 

  • GLUT-4 and Insulin: Glucose uptake into muscle and adipose tissue is fully controlled by insulin, which is secreted by the beta cells of pancreas in response to an increased glucose concentration in the blood.
  • In fasting state, the glucose transporter of muscle and adipose tissue (GLUT-4) is in intracellular vesicles. As insulin secretion falls in the fasting state, the receptors are internalized, reducing glucose uptake.
  • In Fed state: An early response to insulin, migration of these vesicles to the cell surface takes place, where they fuse with the plasma membrane, exposing active glucose transporters.
  • These insulin-sensitive tissues only take up glucose from the bloodstream to any significant extent in the presence of the hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After overnight fasting, insulin levels in the body are low. In insulin-sensitive tissues like adipocytes, low insulin levels lead to a decrease in the number of glucose transporters (such as GLUT4) present on the cell membrane because insulin is required to stimulate the translocation of these transporters from the intracellular stores to the cell surface.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p192.

questions.text: A 27-year-old biochemistry graduate student is presenting her findings on enzyme kinetics at a regional conference. She displays a Lineweaver-Burk plot as part of her presentation, highlighting the utility of this type of graph in determining enzyme kinetics constants. She points out the x-intercept and asks her audience to identify what this value corresponds to in terms of Michaelis-Menten kinetics. Which of the following is equal to the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1/Km

 

Option B.

 

The Lineweaver-Burk plot is a double reciprocal graph of the Michaelis-Menten equation. By plotting 1/V versus 1/[S], a straight line is obtained where the y-intercept is 1/Vmax and the x-intercept is −1/Km. The negative reciprocal of the Michaelis constant (Km) is represented by the x-intercept because the Lineweaver-Burk plot linearizes the hyperbolic curve of the Michaelis-Menten equation, thus allowing for easier calculation of Vmax and Km.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Km: This is incorrect because Km itself is not represented by the x-intercept; rather, its negative reciprocal is.

 

Option C. Km/Vmax: This option is incorrect. While both Km and Vmax are parameters of the Michaelis-Menten equation, the ratio Km/Vmax is not represented by the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Option D. 1/Vmax: This is incorrect because the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax, not the x-intercept.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • With “Double Reciprocal Plot” sometimes it is difficult to achieve high substrate concentrations to reach the maximal velocity conditions.
  • So, ½ Vmax or Km is difficult to determine thus experimental data at lower concentrations is plotted as reciprocals a straight line is obtained when extrapolated to get the reciprocal of Km. This is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal Plot which can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation.
  • If we plot 1/v against 1/[S], it will give a straight-line graph. X intercept is (-1/Km), from which the Km can be calculated.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 80, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 57.

choices.text: Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites
Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

questions.text: While studying the regulation of metabolic pathways, a medical student comes across the concept of allosteric control, particularly its role in enzyme activity. Allosteric enzymes have unique characteristics that differentiate them from other enzymes. Which of the following statements accurately describes a property of allosteric enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

 

Explanation:

 

Allosteric control with negative feedback is indeed a key regulatory mechanism in many metabolic pathways, making option D correct. In negative feedback allosteric regulation, the end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme at an earlier step in the pathway, effectively shutting down production when sufficient product has accumulated. Classic examples include:

  1. Inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) by ATP in glycolysis
  2. Inhibition of aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) by CTP in pyrimidine synthesis

 

Other options: 

 

 

Option A. Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites: This statement is incorrect. By definition, allosteric effectors bind to sites distinct from the active site, called allosteric sites. The term "allosteric" comes from "allo" (other) and "steric" (space or structure), referring to binding at a site other than the active site. When an allosteric effector binds, it induces a conformational change that alters the activity of the enzyme.

 

Option B. Allosteric enzymes possess secondary structure: This statement is correct but not distinctive. All proteins, including enzymes (allosteric or not), possess secondary structure elements such as alpha helices and beta sheets. This is not a unique characteristic of allosteric enzymes.

 

Option C. Allosteric control is irreversible: This is incorrect. Allosteric regulation is typically reversible, allowing for rapid adaptation to changing cellular conditions. When the concentration of the allosteric effector decreases, the enzyme can return to its original conformation and activity state.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Allosteric enzymes are typically oligomeric proteins with multiple subunits that exhibit cooperativity and sigmoidal kinetics rather than the hyperbolic kinetics of Michaelis-Menten enzymes. Their activity can be modulated by effectors binding at sites distinct from the active site, causing conformational changes that alter the enzyme's catalytic efficiency. This provides a rapid, reversible mechanism for regulating metabolic pathways in response to changing cellular needs, with negative feedback being one of the most common control mechanisms in metabolism.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

choices.text: Pantothenic Acid as a part of CoA

questions.text:
There are one specific vitamins, which is involved in the TCA cycle as key for comprehending its biochemical intricacies and the nutritional requirements that support this fundamental metabolic pathway.

 

Which of the following vitamins are involved in the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D:

 

All the listed vitamins are involved in the TCA cycle:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pantothenic Acid:  It is a component of Coenzyme A (CoA), essential for the formation of Acetyl-CoA, a substrate entering the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: It is converted into Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD), a coenzyme used by succinate dehydrogenase in the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Thiamine:  As thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), it is a coenzyme for the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that converts pyruvate into Acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis with the TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamins in TCA Cycle:
 

  • Pantothenic Acid as a part of CoA
  • Riboflavin as FAD
  • Thiamine
  • Niacin as NAD+

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 251.

questions.text: In a groundbreaking study on enzyme diversity, scientists have discovered several enzymes within the same metabolic pathway that, despite differing structurally, perform identical functions across various tissues. This finding prompts a discussion on the classification of these enzymes. Which term accurately describes enzymes with different structures but the same catalytic function?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Isoenzymes

 

Option B.

 

Isoenzymes, or isozymes, are enzyme variants that have different amino acid sequences and may be expressed in different tissues but catalyze the same biochemical reaction. They allow for the fine-tuning of metabolic processes to meet the specific needs of different cells and tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Allosteric enzymes: These are enzymes whose activity can be modulated by the binding of an effector molecule at a site other than the active site (allosteric site). The term "allosteric" does not imply that the enzymes have identical functions but different structures.

 

Option C. Coenzymes: Coenzymes are small, non-protein organic molecules that bind to enzymes and are required for their catalytic activity. They are not enzymes themselves and therefore cannot be classified as having the same catalytic function or different structures.

 

Option D. Apoenzymes: An apoenzyme is the protein component of an enzyme, excluding any cofactors or prosthetic groups. It becomes an active enzyme (holoenzyme) upon binding with its cofactor. This term does not describe enzymes with different structures but identical functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ISOENZYMES:

 

  • Different molecular forms of the same enzyme synthesized in various tissues are called isoenzymes.
  • If the subunits are all the same, the protein is a homomultimer represented by a single gene.
  • If the subunits are different, the protein is a heteromultimer, produced by different genes.
  • They may be products of different genes (more than one locus) known as true isoenzymes.
  • The genes may be located on different chromosomes, e.g. salivary and pancreatic amylase.
  • In certain cases, all the different forms are present in the same individual, e.g. lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) has 5 isoenzymes and all are seen in all persons in the population.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 66, 67.

choices.text: Has higher affinity to glucose compared to glucokinase
Has higher Km to glucose compared to glucokinase
Involved in providing glucose to the peripheral tissues
Not involved in glucose storage by the liver

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with hemolytic anemia, and further investigation reveals a deficiency in hexokinase, a key enzyme in the glycolytic pathway, leading to the premature destruction of energy-depleted red blood cells (RBCs). Which of the following statements about hexokinase is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Has higher Km to glucose compared to Glucokinase

 

Option B:

 

Hexokinase has a lower Km for glucose compared to glucokinase, indicating a higher affinity for glucose. A higher Km would suggest a lower affinity, which is not characteristic of hexokinase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Has higher affinity to glucose compared to Glucokinase.
 

Option C: Involved in providing glucose to the peripheral tissues.

 

Option D: Not involved in glucose storage by the liver

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose to glucose-6-phosphate is converted by either Glucokinase or hexokinase

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 191-192.

questions.text: What is the velocity of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction at the substrate concentration equal to Km?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Half the Vmax          

 

Option D.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of the maximum velocity (Vmax). Therefore, at a substrate concentration equal to Km, the velocity (V) of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction is half of Vmax.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Half the substrate concentration: This option is incorrect because Km is not a measure of velocity but rather a specific substrate concentration.

 

Option B. Same as Vmax: This is incorrect. Vmax is reached only when the enzyme is saturated with substrate, which occurs at a substrate concentration much higher than Km.

 

Option C. Quarter the Vmax: This is also incorrect. The definition of Km specifies that the velocity is half of Vmax, not a quarter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SALIENT FEATURES OF Km:

 

  1. Km value is substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
  2. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration
  3. Km is independent of enzyme concentration.
  4. Km is the signature of the enzyme.
  5. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely related to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex.
  6. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 80-82.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the Correct explanation of A
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong
A is true but R is false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Piericidin and rotenone are inhibitors of (ETC) electron transport chain.

 

Reasoning ®: Piericidin and rotenone inhibits the flow of electron between the complex II and ubiquinone (coenzyme Q)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A is right statement but R is not a correct explanation of statement A.

 

Option D:

 

Explanation:

 

Piericidin and rotenone are indeed inhibitors of the electron transport chain (ETC), specifically affecting the function of Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase). They block the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone (coenzyme Q), not from Complex II. This action inhibits the electron transport chain early in its sequence, preventing the establishment of the proton gradient necessary for ATP synthesis via oxidative phosphorylation. The assertion is correct in stating that these compounds are inhibitors of the ETC, but the reasoning is incorrect as it misidentifies the site of inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 129-134.

questions.text: While preparing for a biochemistry exam, a student revisits the classification system for enzymes established by the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB). The student focuses on translocases, enzymes facilitating the movement of substances across membranes. In the IUBMB system, under which EC number are translocases classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. EC-7

 

Option D.

 

Translocases are categorized under EC-7, a classification introduced to accommodate enzymes that specifically catalyze the translocation of ions and molecules across membranes or their separation within membranes, distinguishing them from other enzymatic activities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. EC-1: This classification is reserved for oxidoreductases, enzymes that catalyze oxidation-reduction reactions, where one molecule is oxidized while another is reduced.

 

Option B. EC-3: Enzymes classified under EC-3 are hydrolases, which catalyze the cleavage of bonds by the addition of water. This includes enzymes like proteases and lipases.

 

Option C. EC-6: This category is for ligases, enzymes that catalyze the joining of two molecules with the concomitant hydrolysis of a diphosphate bond in ATP or a similar triphosphate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 48, 49.

questions.text: Non-protein part of the enzyme can be
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All the above

 

Option D:

 

The non-protein components of enzymes can include coenzymes, cofactors, and prosthetic groups, each playing a vital role in the enzyme's catalytic activity:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Coenzymes: These are organic molecules, often derived from vitamins, that temporarily associate with the enzyme and participate in the reaction by transferring a chemical group from one molecule to another. They are not permanently bound to the enzyme and can be reused in multiple catalytic cycles.

 

Option B. Cofactors: This term encompasses a broader range of non-protein molecules that assist enzymes in their catalytic activity. Cofactors can be metal ions like magnesium, zinc, or iron, which are inorganic, or organic molecules, in which case they are also known as coenzymes. They can be either loosely attached or tightly bound to the enzyme.

 

Option C. Prosthetic groups: These are non-protein components that are tightly, often covalently, bound to the enzyme. They are permanent parts of the enzyme's structure and participate directly in the enzyme's catalytic process. Examples include heme in cytochromes and the biotin in enzymes involved in carboxylation reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymes can be of two types:
    • Simple Enzyme: Consists of only proteins.
    • Complex enzyme consists of: Protein part: Apoenzyme and Nonprotein part
  • Apoenzyme + Non Protein part (Prosthetic group/Cofactor/ Coenzyme) = Holoenzyme
  • Nonprotein parts can be Coenzyme, Cofactor and Prosthetic group.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 50.

questions.text: Which of the following examples best illustrates the concept of enzyme induction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ALA synthase by barbiturates

 

Option A.

 

  • Induction is effected through the process of derepression. 
  • The inducer will relieve the repression on the operator site and will remove the block on the biosynthesis of the enzyme molecules.
  • E.g: Induction of lactose-utilizing enzymes in the bacteria when the media contains lactose in the absence of glucose.
  • Tryptophan pyrrolase and transaminases are induced by glucocorticoids.
  • Glucokinase is induced by insulin.
  • ALA synthase is induced by barbiturates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase by malonate: e.g of competitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Cytochromes by cyanide: e.g of Non-competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. ALA synthase by heme: e.g: of Repression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barbiturates can induce the synthesis of ALA synthase, an enzyme involved in the heme synthesis pathway, by increasing the transcription of its gene. This is an example of enzyme induction where the presence of a compound (barbiturates) increases the production and activity of an enzyme.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 64.

questions.text: A young woman with laboratory picture of normocytic anaemia and jaundice with splenomegaly was diagnosed to have RBC pyruvate kinase deficiency after a PBS showed spiculated cells. Due to the abnormal function of pyruvate kinase, less pyruvate is formed and the intermediates above pyruvate in the glycolytic pathway get accumulated. Which of the following products is not formed in appropriate amounts in the RBC due to the deficiency of pyruvate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lactate 

 

Option A:

 

Pyruvate kinase catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate in the final step of glycolysis, generating ATP. In pyruvate kinase deficiency, this reaction is impaired, resulting in reduced pyruvate production.

 

In red blood cells, which rely exclusively on anaerobic glycolysis for energy production, pyruvate is normally converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). This reaction regenerates NAD+ from NADH, allowing glycolysis to continue. When pyruvate kinase is deficient, less pyruvate is produced, consequently leading to decreased lactate formation.

 

 

Other options: 

 

Option B. Oxaloacetate: Mature RBCs lack mitochondria and therefore do not contain the enzymes needed to convert pyruvate to oxaloacetate (via pyruvate carboxylase). Oxaloacetate is not normally produced in RBCs regardless of pyruvate kinase function.

 

Option C. Acetyl-CoA: Similar to oxaloacetate, acetyl-CoA formation from pyruvate requires the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which is located in mitochondria. Since mature RBCs lack mitochondria, they do not produce acetyl-CoA from pyruvate.

 

Option D. Glucose: RBCs do not synthesize glucose from pyruvate (gluconeogenesis). This process requires several enzymes that are not present in RBCs and also occurs primarily in the liver and kidneys.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

This question tests understanding of RBC metabolism, particularly the consequences of pyruvate kinase deficiency. Pyruvate kinase deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects glycolysis in RBCs, leading to premature destruction of red blood cells (hemolytic anemia). The spiculated RBCs seen on peripheral blood smear are characteristic of this condition. The defect causes ATP depletion, accumulation of glycolytic intermediates upstream of the enzyme defect, and reduced production of downstream metabolites like lactate.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 170; Vasudevan 9/e: 111.

questions.text: Which enzyme catalyzes the substrate-level phosphorylation step in the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Succinyl CoA synthetase

 

Option C:

 

Formation of succinate:

 

  • The enzyme is succinate thiokinase / Succinyl-CoA Synthetase (step 5 of TCA cycle).
  • A molecule of GDP is phosphorylated to GTP and succinate is formed.
  • The GTP can be converted to ATP by reacting with an ADP molecule:

                                      GTP + ADP → GDP + ATP

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Isocitrate dehydrogenase- Catalyzes step 3 of TCA cycle.

 

Option B: α- ketoglutarate dehydrogenase - Catalyzes step 4 of TCA cycle.

 

Option C: Succinate dehydrogenase- Catalyzes step 6 of TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Succinyl CoA synthetase catalyzes the only substrate-level phosphorylation step within the TCA cycle, where GDP (guanosine diphosphate) is phosphorylated to GTP (guanosine triphosphate), which can then be converted to ATP. This step involves the conversion of succinyl CoA to succinate.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 247-249.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the Michaelis-Menten equation accurately?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V = Vmax X [S] / Km + [S]

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The Michaelis-Menten equation describes the relationship between substrate concentration ([S]) and reaction velocity (Vi) for an enzyme-catalyzed reaction:

 

V= Vmax x S / Km + S

 

Where:

  • V = velocity of Reaction 
    • Vmax = Maximum reaction velocity
    • [S] = Substrate concentration
    • Km = Michaelis constant (substrate concentration at half Vmax)
  • This equation shows that the reaction velocity increases hyperbolically with increasing substrate concentration.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 79.

questions.text: Which of the following kinetic constants is the best measure for expressing the ‘CATALYTIC EFFICIENCY OF AN ENZYME’?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kcat/Km  

                                 

Option C.

 

  • Catalytic efficiency is used to quantify and compare the efficiency of different enzymes, different substrates for a given enzyme and the efficiency with which an enzyme catalyzes a reaction in the forward and reverse directions.
  • It is usually expressed as the ratio of Kcat divided by Km
  • Enzyme activity is expressed as micromoles of substrate converted to product per minute under specified assay conditions and its modern method of expression is in Katals (kat)
  • One standard unit (or International Unit) of enzyme activity (U) : amount of enzyme that will convert one micromole of substrate per minute per litre of sample and is abbreviated as U/L
  • One Katal (catalytic activity) is defined as the number of mol of substrate transformed per second per litre of sample (Kcat = Vmax divided by the number of active sites).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ka/Km: This option is not correct as Ka (association constant) is not typically used in the context of enzyme catalysis.

 

Option B. Km/Kcat: This is the inverse of the correct answer and would indicate lower efficiency with increasing values, which is contrary to the concept of catalytic efficiency.

 

Option D. Km/Ka: Similarly to option b, this ratio would not correctly represent catalytic efficiency as it suggests higher values indicate higher efficiency, which is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is best expressed as the ratio Kcat/Km. Kcat is the turnover number, which represents the number of substrate molecules converted to product per enzyme molecule per unit time.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: P 80, Lippincott 7/e: P 54

questions.text: A research team is exploring the metabolic adaptations of cancer cells and how these cells meet their increased energy demands. In most cancer cells, the predominant metabolic pathway for generating the necessary energy is distinct from that of normal, non-cancerous cells. Which metabolic process do cancer cells primarily exploit to derive the energy needed for their rapid growth and proliferation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycolysis

 

Option A:
 

  • In 1924, the biochemist Otto Warburg and his colleagues discovered that cancer cells take up large amounts of glucose and metabolize it to lactic acid, even in the presence of oxygen.
  • This observation is known as the Warburg effect.
  • Based on these data, Warburg made two hypotheses:
  1. The increased ratio of glycolysis to aerobic respiration was due to defects in the mitochondrial respiratory chain
  2. This enhanced glycolysis enabled cancer cells to proliferate in the reduced oxygen tension often seen in tumours.
  • Thus, the switching from aerobic to anaerobic glucose metabolism was the driver of tumorigenesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Oxidative phosphorylation: While important in many tissues, cancer cells rely less on oxidative phosphorylation compared to normal cells, partially because it is less efficient under hypoxic conditions, which are common in tumors.

 

Option C. TCA cycle in mitochondria: The TCA cycle is used by all cells, but cancer cells often have mitochondrial defects that reduce their reliance on this pathway.

 

Option D. Beta-oxidation: This pathway oxidizes fatty acids to generate acetyl-CoA for energy; however, cancer cells typically rely on this less than on glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cancer cells predominantly use glycolysis for energy production, even in the presence of oxygen, a phenomenon known as the Warburg effect. This metabolic adaptation allows cancer cells to thrive even under hypoxic conditions and contributes to the acidic microenvironment often seen in tumors due to lactate production.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p738.

questions.text: During the conversion of -ketoglutarate to succinate in the TCA cycle, several reactions occur, leading to the production of energy-rich molecules. This conversion involves the decarboxylation of -ketoglutarate, the generation of Succinyl CoA, and the subsequent formation of succinate. how many ATP molecules are typically produced through this series of reactions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3.5

 

Explanation:

 

The conversion of -ketoglutarate to succinate in the TCA cycle involves two key steps:

  1. First, -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of -ketoglutarate to form succinyl-CoA, CO, and NADH.
    • The NADH produced in this step will yield approximately 2.5 ATP molecules when oxidized through the electron transport chain.
  2. Second, succinyl-CoA synthetase (also called succinate thiokinase) catalyzes the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate with the generation of GTP (which is energetically equivalent to ATP.
    • This substrate-level phosphorylation directly produces 1 GTP/ATP molecule.

 

Therefore, the total ATP yield from converting -ketoglutarate to succinate is:

  • 2.5 ATP from NADH oxidation in the electron transport chain
  • 1 ATP from substrate-level phosphorylation (GTP formation)
  • Total: 3.5 ATP molecules 

 

This makes option C (3.5) the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the energetics of the TCA cycle reactions, specifically:

  • The -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex reaction produces NADH
  • The succinyl-CoA synthetase reaction produces GTP/ATP via substrate-level phosphorylation
  • NADH yields approximately 2.5 ATP when oxidized through the electron transport chain
  • Together, these reactions yield 3.5 ATP molecules from the conversion of -ketoglutarate to succinate

questions.text: How should the following inhibitors be matched with their corresponding complexes or sites?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cyanide is known to inhibit Complex IV of the electron transport chain by binding to the cytochrome c oxidase, preventing the transfer of electrons to oxygen and thereby halting ATP synthesis.
  • Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II), specifically inhibiting the site between succinate dehydrogenase and Co-Q (coenzyme Q).
  • BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) does not directly inhibit any specific complex within the electron transport chain; thus, its inclusion might be misleading. However, in the context of this question and the available options, it is matched with b, but this is not reflective of its actual function.
  • Chlorpromazine is not a classical inhibitor of the electron transport chain, and its inclusion in this list might not be accurate for educational purposes. However, based on the available options, it is matched with a, Complex I to Co-Q.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 266.

questions.text: MATCH THE FOLLOWING
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

Kinases - c) ATP: Kinases are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of phosphate groups from high-energy, phosphate-donating molecules, such as ATP, to specific substrates.

 

Transaminase - a) Pyridoxal phosphate: Transaminases, also known as aminotransferases, are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of an amino group from an amino acid to a keto acid. They commonly use pyridoxal phosphate, a derivative of vitamin B6, as a coenzyme.

 

Alpha Keto Dehydrogenase - d) Lipoic acid: Alpha-keto dehydrogenases are a class of enzymes that catalyze the decarboxylation of alpha-keto acids. Lipoic acid is often involved as a coenzyme in their complexes.

 

Carboxylases - b) Biotin: Carboxylases are enzymes that catalyze the addition of a carboxyl group to a substrate. Biotin, a B vitamin, serves as a coenzyme for these enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 350.

questions.text: A graph is presented depicting enzyme kinetics with and without an inhibitor. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows two lines intersecting on the y-axis. The line representing enzyme activity with an inhibitor has a different slope than that without an inhibitor, yet both lines intersect at the same point on the y-axis. Based on this information, what type of enzyme inhibition is being represented in this plot?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Competitive

 

Explanation:

 

In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax, and the x-intercept represents 1/Km. In competitive inhibition:

  • The inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding at the active site.
  • This leads to an increase in Km (i.e., substrate affinity appears reduced).
  • However, since high substrate concentrations can outcompete the inhibitor, Vmax remains unchanged.

 

Thus, in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, lines for inhibited and uninhibited enzyme intersect at the y-axis (same Vmax), but have different slopes due to increased Km exactly as described in the question.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B (Uncompetitive): In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows parallel lines, not intersecting at the y-axis.
  • Option C (Non-competitive): This affects Vmax (lowered) but not Km, and the plot shows lines intersecting on the x-axis, not y.
  • Option D (Suicidal): Irreversible inhibition with no fixed pattern on the Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with substrate for the enzymes active site, increasing Km without affecting Vmax. In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, this is seen as lines intersecting on the y-axis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

questions.text: In an enzyme kinetics experiment, a substrate concentration 1000 times the Km value resulted in the conversion of 1% of the substrate into 12 µmol of product in 9 minutes with a certain enzyme amount. In a modified experiment, one-third of the initial enzyme amount is used with double the initial substrate concentration. How long would it take to produce the same amount (12 µmol) of product in the modified experiment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 27 minutes

 Option A.                                                              

  • Zero-Order Reactions. In some reactions, the rate is apparently independent of the substrate concentration. The rates of these zero-order reactions do not vary with increasing nor decreasing substrate concentrations.
  • First-order reaction. : the rate of reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the substrate
  • Km : Substrate concentration at which the velocity is half maximum
  • Usually reactions follow zero order Kinetics if substrate concentration is > 10 times of Km value. Here substrate concentration is 1000Km which means irrespective of increasing substrate concentration the reaction won’t be affected.
  • First experiment mentions that 12 µmol products are formed in 9 minutes.
  • In the second experiment the enzyme concentration is reduced to 1/3rd. so the time taken to form the same amount of product will be tripled. Thus the answer is 27 minutes

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reaction rate at or near Vmax is less affected by substrate concentration and more by enzyme concentration. Reducing enzyme to one-third decreases the rate to one-third, extending production time for 12 µmol of product to 27 minutes.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 76-79.

questions.text: A research team is investigating the digestion of dietary proteins and employs chymotrypsin to understand the breakdown process. Chymotrypsin, a digestive enzyme, is known for its specificity in targeting peptide bonds. In assessing the activity of chymotrypsin, the team is particularly interested in identifying the amino acid residues that, when positioned at the carbonyl side of a peptide bond, are most susceptible to cleavage by this enzyme. Which amino acid residue is chymotrypsin most likely to cleave at the carbonyl terminal side of a peptide bond?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phenylalanine

 

Option A.

 

Chymotrypsin selectively cleaves peptide bonds at the carbonyl terminal of aromatic amino acids, with phenylalanine being one of the preferred residues. This specificity is due to the enzyme's ability to accommodate the bulky aromatic side chains in its active site.

 

  • Serine Proteases are proteolytic enzymes with Serine at their active Site
  • Amino acid triad in the active site of Serine Proteases: Ser, His, Asp.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Arginine: While arginine is a basic amino acid with a significant role in various biochemical processes, chymotrypsin does not preferentially cleave at the carbonyl terminal of arginine residues.

 

Option C. Lysine: Similar to arginine, lysine is a basic amino acid. Chymotrypsin's specificity for aromatic side chains means it does not typically cleave peptide bonds at the carbonyl terminal of lysine residues.

 

Option D. Glycine: Glycine, being a small and flexible amino acid, does not fit the specificity profile of chymotrypsin, which favors larger, aromatic residues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examples of serine proteases

 

  • Chymotrypsin
  • Trypsin
  • Elastase
  • Thrombin
  • Plasmin
  • Complements
  • Factor X and XI.

 

Serine proteases differ in substrate specificity

 

  • Trypsin cleaves adjacent to Basic Amino Acid like Arg, Lys.
  • Chymotrypsin cleaves adjacent to Hydrophobic Bulky Amino Acid like Trp, Tyr, Phe
  • Elastase cleaves adjacent to Small neutral Amino Acids like Alanine, Glycine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 64.

questions.text:
Examines the following diagram, illustrating the PDH complex and its enzymatic

 

 

 

components, labelled A, B, and C

 

What is the name of enzyme component 'C' within the PDH complex?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase        

 

Option D:

 

Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) is the third enzyme in the PDH complex and is responsible for the reoxidation of the lipoamide groups in the complex. It transfers the electrons to NAD+, reducing it to NADH, which is then used in other metabolic processes such as the electron transport chain.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: This is the first enzyme in the complex and is responsible for the decarboxylation of pyruvate.

 

Option B. Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase: The second enzyme in the complex, responsible for transferring the acetyl group to CoA to form acetyl-CoA.

 

Option C. Lipoamide: Not an enzyme but rather a cofactor bound to the enzymes in the PDH complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The enzyme part of the PDH complex is made up of three component enzymes.
  • PYRUVATE DEHYDROGENASE (ENZYME 1): Catalyses oxidative decarboxylation; Coenzyme: TPP; Enzyme bound hydroxyethyl TPP is formed
  • DIHYDRO LIPOYL TRANSACETYLASE (ENZYME 2): Hydroxyethyl group is oxidized to form acetyl group → transferred from TPP to lipoamide → acetyl lipoamide.
  • DIHYDROLIPOYL DEHYDROGENASE (ENZYME 3): Oxidation of lipoamide; cofactors: TPP, lipoamide and FAD are regenerated

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 173, Vasudevan 9/ ed: p 115

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes fits the definition of a lyase?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aldolase B

 

Option A.

 

Aldolase B is a type of lyase that specifically catalyzes the cleavage of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate into glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the glycolysis pathway. This reaction involves the breaking of a C-C bond, which is characteristic of lyase activity.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is classified as an oxidoreductase. It catalyzes the interconversion of pyruvate and lactate with concomitant interconversion of NADH and NAD+.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine esterase: This enzyme is a hydrolase, not a lyase. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of acetylcholine into choline and acetate, a critical reaction in the function of the nervous system.

 

Option D. Acetyl CoA carboxylase: This enzyme is a ligase (more specifically, a biotin-dependent carboxylase). It catalyzes the ATP-dependent carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to produce malonyl-CoA, a key step in fatty acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some examples of Lyases are:

 

  1. HMG CoA Lyase
  2. Argininosuccinate Lyase
  3. ATP Citrate Lyase
  4. Aldolase
  5. Fumarase

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 49.

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the glycolytic pathway and is attempting to identify the points of regulation within the process. She notes that certain steps are irreversible and thus play a key role in the regulation of glycolysis. Which of the following enzymes catalyzes a reaction in glycolysis that is not considered irreversible and therefore not a major regulatory point?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enolase

 

Option A:

 

Enolase catalyzes the second-to-last step in aerobic glycolysis, converting 2-phosphoglycerate into phosphoenolpyruvate. This step is reversible and not a major control point in the pathway. In contrast, the other enzymes listed catalyze irreversible steps and are tightly regulated to control the flow through the glycolytic pathway.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Catalyzes an irreversible step by converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate and is a major regulatory point of glycolysis.

 

Option C. Pyruvate Kinase: Irreversibly Catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, another regulatory step in glycolysis.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Irreversibly phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate at the start of the glycolytic pathway and is allosterically inhibited by its product, making it a key regulatory enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irreversible Steps of Glycolysis:

  • Hexokinase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate Kinase

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p170-172.

choices.text: Can incorporate 2 atoms of O2 in a substance
Can incorporate 1 atom of O2 in a substance
Important in hydroxylation of steroids

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic steroid use for rheumatoid arthritis presents with altered liver enzymes. Given his medication history, the physician is concerned about the impact on hepatic enzyme functions, especially those involved in steroid metabolism. Which enzyme characteristic is least associated with steroid metabolism in this patient's liver?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Catalysed carboxylation of drugs.

 

Option D.

 

Carboxylation reactions, which involve the addition of a carboxyl group to a molecule, are not typically associated with the hepatic metabolism of steroids. Steroid metabolism primarily involves reactions such as hydroxylation, which is facilitated by enzymes capable of incorporating oxygen atoms into the steroid molecule.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorporation of two oxygen atoms into substrates: Dioxygenases can incorporate two oxygen atoms from O2 into substrates. While important in some metabolic pathways, this activity is less common in the direct metabolism of steroids by the liver.

 

Option B. Hydroxylation of steroids: This is a key reaction in the metabolism of steroids, involving the addition of an OH group. Enzymes like cytochrome P450s, which incorporate one oxygen atom into the substrate, often facilitate this reaction.

 

Option C. Incorporation of one oxygen atom into substrates: This describes the activity of monooxygenases, such as those in the cytochrome P450 family, which are crucial for the hydroxylation of steroids in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxygenases can be monooxygenase or dioxygenase.
  • Monooxygenase can incorporate 1 atom of oxygen molecule to the substrate.
  • Dioxygenase can incorporate both the atoms of oxygen molecules to the substrate.
  • Phase 1 Xenobiotic reactions such as hydroxylation is catalysed mainly by members of a class of enzymes known as monooxygenases or cytochrome P450s.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p118, 119.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the enzyme inhibition shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.   Allosteric inhibition

 

Option D.

 

  • Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site for the substrate to bind and another separate allosteric site for the modifier to bind.
  • Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  • The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme (allosteric activation) or inhibit the activity of the enzyme (allosteric inhibition).
  • The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Competitive inhibition: This would typically result in an increase in the apparent Km (decreased affinity) without affecting Vmax, and the graph would show a Michaelis-Menten curve, not a sigmoidal one.

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibition: This generally results in a decreased Vmax while the Km remains unchanged; the graph would still follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive inhibition: This occurs when an inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a parallel decrease in both Km and Vmax, which is not shown in the provided graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salient features of allosteric inhibition:

 

  1. The inhibitor is not a substrate analog.
  2. It is partially reversible, when excess substrate is added.
  3. Km is increased and Vmax is reduced.
  4. The effect of allosteric modifier is maximum at or near substrate concentration equivalent to Km.
  5. Most allosteric enzymes possess quaternary structure. They are made up of subunits, e.g. Aspartate transcarbamoylase has 6 subunits and pyruvate kinase has 4 subunits.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

questions.text: Among the listed enzymes, which one is NOT typically considered a non-functional enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lipoprotein lipase

 

Explanation:

 

Enzymes found in the plasma can be classified into two types:

 

Non-functional (plasma marker) enzymes:

  • These do not perform any physiological function in plasma.
  • Their presence in serum is typically due to cell damage or turnover.
  • Elevated levels help identify tissue injury or disease.
  • Examples:
    • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) bone and liver disorders
    • Acid phosphatase prostate conditions
    • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) hepatobiliary dysfunction
    • LDH, CK, AST used as diagnostic markers

 

Functional (plasma active) enzymes:

  • These perform essential metabolic functions within the circulation.
  • They are actively secreted into plasma to carry out physiological roles.

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a classic functional enzyme:

  • It hydrolyzes triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids and glycerol.
  • Plays a critical role in lipid metabolism and energy distribution.

 

Other Options:

  • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
    Non-functional enzyme; diagnostic marker for bone and hepatobiliary diseases.
  • Acid phosphatase
    Non-functional; historically used to detect prostate cancer.
  • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)
    Non-functional; useful in assessing alcoholic liver disease and cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipoprotein lipase is a functional plasma enzyme, directly involved in lipid metabolism.
  • In contrast, non-functional enzymes like ALP, ACP, GGT do not have roles in the plasma but serve as important clinical markers of tissue damage.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 301.

questions.text: In a case study involving the analysis of a new drug's mechanism of action, it's observed that the drug inhibits an enzyme by resembling the enzyme's natural substrate and competing for the active site. Given this mode of inhibition, how would this type of enzyme inhibition be classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Competitive inhibition

 

  • Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme, because the inhibitor is a structural analogue of the substrate.

           E + S <-> E–S → E + P

           E + I  <-> E–I

  • Since E-I (enzyme–inhibitor complex) can react only to reform the enzyme and inhibitor, the number of enzyme molecules available for E-S formation is reduced.

 

 

  • Competitive inhibition is reversible or excess substrate abolishes the inhibition.
  • The Km is increased in presence of a competitive inhibitor, thus the affinity of the enzyme towards the substrate is apparently decreased and Vmax is not changed.     

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibition: Inhibitors have no structural resemblance to the substrate.

 

Option C. Feedback inhibition: The activity of the enzyme is inhibited by the product of the reaction.

 

Option D. Allosteric inhibition: The inhibitor is not a substrate analog.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor molecule resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the enzyme's active site. This type of inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate, as both the substrate and inhibitor compete for the same site on the enzyme.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 59.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical research team is investigating a new drug that targets an enzyme involved in the metabolic pathway of a particular hormone. This enzyme is known for its ability to catalyze the rearrangement of atoms within the hormone molecule, effectively altering its shape without changing its chemical composition. Such a transformation is crucial for the hormone's activation and subsequent biological function. Based on the enzyme's action, which category does it belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Isomerase

 

Option D.

 

Isomerases are a class of enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule, allowing the molecule to be converted into its isomers. These changes can involve the rearrangement of bonds within a molecule, changing the molecule's shape without adding or removing atoms. This class of enzymes is crucial for various metabolic pathways where the conversion of one isomer to another is necessary for the pathway's continuation or regulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lyase: Lyases catalyze the addition or removal of groups to or from double bonds, or other formations and cleavages of double bonds through means other than hydrolysis and oxidation. They are not primarily involved in isomerization reactions.

 

Option B. Oxidoreductase: Oxidoreductases are involved in oxidation-reduction reactions, where electrons are transferred from one molecule to another. These enzymes are key players in cellular respiration and photosynthesis but do not typically catalyze structural or geometric changes within a single molecule.

 

Option C. Ligase: Ligases catalyze the joining of two molecules with the simultaneous hydrolysis of a diphosphate bond in ATP or a similar triphosphate. They are essential for processes like DNA replication and repair but are not responsible for isomerization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The International Union of Biochemistry (IUB) developed an unambiguous system of enzyme nomenclature in which each enzyme has a unique name and code number that identifies the type of reaction catalyzed and the substrates involved.
  • Enzymes are grouped into six classes.
  1. Oxidoreductases: enzymes that catalyze oxidations and reductions.
  2. Transferases: enzymes that catalyze transfer of moieties such as glycosyl, methyl, or phosphoryl groups.
  3. Hydrolases: enzymes that catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.
  4. Lyases: enzymes that catalyze cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, generating double bonds.
  5. Isomerases: enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
  6. Ligases: enzymes that catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 61.

questions.text: One specialized organ in mammals has a unique adaptation that allows it to utilize fuel oxidation not primarily for ATP production but for the generation of heat, aiding in thermoregulation. Which of the following is this specialized organ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brown adipose tissue

 

Option C:

 

Brown adipose tissue gets its colour due to the high density of mitochondria in the individual adipose cells and new-born babies have it in their neck and upper back which serves the function of non-shivering thermogenesis.

 

Brown adipose tissue contains thermogenin, which is a physiological uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation.

 

The muscle contractions take place in the process of shivering not only generate ATP but also produce heat.

 

Non-shivering thermogenesis is a hormonal stimulus for heat generation without the associated muscle contractions of shivering.

 

This process in brown fat is initiated by the release of free fatty acids from the triglycerides stored in the adipose cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The adrenal gland is involved in hormone production, including stress and metabolic hormones, but it is not primarily associated with heat generation.

 

Option B: Skeletal muscle can produce heat through shivering thermogenesis, where muscle contractions generate heat, but this is not its primary function.

 

Option D: The heart's primary function is to pump blood throughout the body, and while it does produce heat as a byproduct of its metabolic activities, it is not specialized for heat production like brown adipose tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown adipose tissue is the specialized organ in mammals designed for heat production through non-shivering thermogenesis, emphasizing its role in thermoregulation and energy metabolism.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 162, 267.

questions.text: Identify which of the following pathways does not produce high-energy phosphate compounds directly helps in comprehending the energy dynamics within the cell.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HMP Pathway.

 

Option B:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) pathway, also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), is primarily involved in the production of NADPH and pentoses (5-carbon sugars) rather than the direct synthesis of high-energy phosphate compounds like ATP or GTP. NADPH is crucial for biosynthetic reactions and antioxidant defense, but the pathway itself does not directly produce high-energy phosphate compounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TCA cycle: This cycle includes steps that produce high-energy phosphate compounds, such as the substrate-level phosphorylation generating GTP.

 

Option C. Glycolysis: Glycolysis directly produces ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation in two steps.

 

Option D. Beta-Oxidation of Fatty Acid - Each cycle of beta-oxidation generates FADH2 and NADH, which contribute to ATP synthesis through oxidative phosphorylation, albeit indirectly. However, considering the overall process and its contribution to ATP generation, it's included among the pathways that produce high-energy compounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathways which do not synthesize ATP are
 

  • HMP Pathway
  • Rapaport Luebering Cycle
  • Uronic acid pathway
  • Alpha oxidation of Fatty acid
  • Omega Oxidation of fatty acid

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 253.

questions.text: In cardiac diagnostics, clinicians often refer to the LDH isoenzyme ratio as an indicator of myocardial infarction (MI). In a typical healthy adult, the LDH-2 level is higher than LDH-1. A condition where this ratio is reversed, with LDH-1 being higher than LDH-2, is sometimes described in clinical practice. Is the term "flipped pattern" correctly applied to the scenario where LDH-2 is higher than LDH-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False     

 

Explanation

 

Healthy individual has LDH-2 higher than LDH-1. After certain types of myocardial injury, such as an MI, cardiac cells release more LDH-1 than LDH-2, which can lead to LDH-1 becoming higher than LDH-2. This reversal is what's referred to as a "flipped pattern," so the statement LDH-2 >>> LDH-1 being known as a flipped pattern is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question tests understanding of LDH isoenzyme patterns in normal and pathological states. The five LDH isoenzymes (LDH-1 through LDH-5) consist of different combinations of H (heart) and M (muscle) subunits. LDH-1 (H) predominates in heart tissue, LDH-5 (M) predominates in liver and skeletal muscle, and the others are hybrid forms. The normal serum pattern (LDH-2 > LDH-1) gets reversed in myocardial infarction, creating the "flipped pattern" (LDH-1 > LDH-2). While historically important, LDH isoenzyme analysis has been largely replaced by more specific cardiac markers such as troponin in modern clinical practice.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 69.
